captions.text: Introducing the LaFerrari. Ferrari builds cars like this roughly once every
decade.
This one accomplishes 3 feats of appropriate magnitude:
1) With 954 horsepower combined its the most powerful
Ferrari ever. 2) It's the first hybrid

Ferrari ever, and 3) It's named after the
company.
You thought the Enzo had shoes to fill.
As you would expect it represents the top tier of Ferrari technology.

The carbon fiber tub for example is
built by the same team

that makes the Formula-1 cars, and it's
baked in the same auto place.
Our time behind the wheel took place at a brief day at Ferrari's
home court the morning at the 1.9 mile Fiorano development track,

and the afternoon on the mountain roads
surrounding the factory.
We only had roughly eight laps at Fiorano.
But it was impressive how easy the LaFerrari was to drive.

Not to say it was un-intimidating you're
certainly aware of the awesome power,
but the learning curve felt approachable.
So I've just done a lapping session in the LaFerrari.
And it's a hell of a car!
There is
pretty much ridiculous power everywhere,
but it's the power delivery
that's so interesting. The e-motor
that's working on the differential and trans axel
just applies this immediacy
to the throttle response
that I didn't believe this V-12 needed before driving this car, but now
I'm a fan of it because it just makes
the engine so much more powerful.
Like right there just that
instantaneous throttle response.
And this engine was already powerful but, now it just seems
even more.
Another interesting thing is the steering wheel.

It's kinda big, has a big airy on the
center to play with,
but once you start dialing in steering angle the gain is really quick
in that it seems to turn
more expressive the more you
turn the wheel.

Such that you're doing like a quarter turn to
basically do a 180.
Like I'm about a quarter there
on a, you know, decently
long corner.
It's crazy.
I can dive on the brakes at 260 Km/hr
there
having done three laps in the car total. And that's fine I do it without a problem.
I always forget there's a turn there.
This thing is phenomenal, woo (laughs).

Then this car very much makes you feel
good about yourself.
The LaFerrari looks deceivingly small.
It's actually longer and wider than the McLaren P1 and Porsche 918.

Though it's shorter in height than both it's a
beautiful car in detail

from the side view mirrors to the
accentuated blackbody gap that evokes
all the great
Ferraris: 288 GTO, F-40 and F-50 and so on.

My favorite part is the rear how the
black line meets the tail lights how
the exhaust pipes

poke out to the lower wings and of course
the F1 light at the bottom.
As a whole it has this eye-catching and somewhat alien aura.

Looking like a product of Ferrari from
the year 2025.

Ferrari claims zero to sixty
acceleration takes less than 3 seconds.

A cautious estimate especially compared
to the McLaren P1 we tested.

I brought along our trusty V-box to
validate Ferrari's performance claims,

but the company refused to let us test
the car. We'll have to wait to test one later.
So typically when we do these things: drive some Italian supercar on the

road you realize it's just an exercise in
frustration. The roads are just too tight, you have too much power,
any can't really do anything that's fun.

It's very different in this car and that's
crazy this is a 950 horsepower
Ferrari and I'm finding I enjoy it on the road
a lot for reasons like that.

Stability control is smart it gives me the
amount of control I want.
The trans is shifting

pretty much where I want it to for this
road. I'm staying right
in the torque.

I'm having a great time and this is, this is a
weird experience

considering that Ferrari has spent so much
time on the ergonomics of this car.
And they've got it right.
When has Ferrari ever cared about ergonomics and here we are
in a car that nails it.
First having no seat structure the seat's bolted right to the tub.

And that means your body is just part of
what the chassis is doing. Your body's

feeling everything. You can sense
every action in the car
right through the seat there's no structure to dampen
those forces.
It's quite an impressive feat that the car as a whole feels so solid and controllable and
easy to drive.
It's really amazing!
This thing drives so well on the road I almost prefer doing this than doing it
on the racetrack.
So much fun to hustle this valuable, this powerful,
this technological of a car along a mountain road. It's really good.

Of course the LaFerrari would perform
excellently on the racetrack
the roads but developed on.

Even with that in mind I didn't wanna
stop driving it.

The performance was everything you'd
hope: stunning acceleration, consistent
acceleration, powerful braking,
and high lateral limits.

But as spectacular as those things were
it was LaFerrari's sheer ability on the road
that impressed most.
As we were wrapping the day's shoot the thought entered my brain.

This may be the best road car I've ever
driven.
And you look over and you see some
villa off in the Italian countryside and you go oh yes
all is right in the world.

comments.author: SilverArrow WilliamsMartini

comments.text:
I, just like everyone else, want to see a head to head to head comparison 
of LaFerrari, P1, and 918. I want to see this because all three of these 
cars represent the bleeding edge of technology in road cars. The P1 and the 
918 have gone head to head because they don't have the the same bullshit 
rules that Ferrari places on their owners. I don't know why Ferrari does 
this, because it makes the public feel as though Ferrari is afraid of being 
beaten. Ferrari wants the LaFerrari's reputation to compete with 
reputations of both the P1 and the 918 without the LaFerrari actually 
having to physically compete with them. It looks like nothing less than 
cowardice on Ferrari's part. I don't know how you can go on being willingly 
ignorant about this all while accusing me of not "interpreting this into my 
brain" an accusation which by the way doesn't make any sense at all. I can 
interpret something with my brain, and I can put information "into my 
brain". If you were actually capable of formulating an insult that wasn't 
pathetic, you would have said something like, "Is your brain so feeble that 
it is not capable of interpreting this information?". I will, however, give 
you the benefit of the doubt and assume that English is not your first 
language.
comments.author: sirdavidspagnolo

comments.text:
+sirdavidspagnolo I wasn't talking about McLaren and Porsche's limited 
edition cars. I was just saying Ferrari lets the media compare their 
models, except their limited edition cars like LaFerrari. How can you not 
read and interpret this into your brain?

comments.text:
Great question to ask. Many factors are involved here. Crash standards will 
be raised soon like here in the states. This does limit the designers in 
some areas of most cars. Just look at the Mclaren F1. The team behind that 
car had do such rules to follow. Aerodynamics is probably the biggest 
reason too. Every 1 wants a car that has nice downforce but minimum drag at 
the same time.
So don't expect much to change soon in any newer hyper cars,supercars or 
any other so called sports cars.
